com.smartsockets
Class TipcSvc

java.lang.Object
  com.smartsockets.TipcSvc
public class TipcSvc
extends java.lang.Object

A static factory class for the TipcMt, TipcMsg, TipcConnClient, TipcConnServer, and TipcSrv interfaces. Objects of the required concrete classes that implement these interfaces are created with this class.

For example, to create a connection to the RTserver and to create and send a SmartSockets message on the connection, you would do the following: 

    // get the connection to the RTserver from the factory
    TipcSrv srv = TipcSvc.getSrv();

    // create an INFO message from the factory
    TipcMsg msg = TipcSvc.createMsg(TipcMt.INFO);

    // publish the INFO message to the "/foo" subject on the connection
    msg.setDest("/foo");
    srv.send(msg);

Method Detail

createMt

public static TipcMt createMt(java.lang.String name,
                              int number,
                              java.lang.String grammar)
                       throws TipcException

Defines a new message type.

Once a message type is defined, it may be looked up with the name and number lookup functions.

For example, to define a new message type named "foo", which has the number '500', and is intended to take two integer fields and a string field, you'd do this: 

   TipcMt mt = TipcSvc.createMt("foo", 500, "int4 int4 str");

You may use the TipcMt object directly, or look up the instance by name or number, like any other predefined message type: 

   // look up a message type by name
   TipcMt mt = TipcSvc.lookupMt("foo");

   // look up a message type by number
   TipcMt mt = TipcSvc.lookupMt(500);

Parameters:
name - name of the new message type.
number - reference number of the new message type. Numbers less than 1 are reserved for SmartSockets standard message types. A message number of 0 should not be used.
grammar - printable grammar for the new message type. The grammer identifies the type and order of fields in the message type, and is used when printing a message of this type.
Returns:
a new object implementing the TipcMt interface.
Throws:
TipcAlreadyExistsException - an attempt was made to create a message type using a name or number that is already used by an existing message type.
TipcException - for all other errors
See Also:
TipcMt, lookupMt(String), lookupMt(int)

lookupMt

public static TipcMt lookupMt(java.lang.String name)
Returns the message type indexed by name. This message type must be one of the standard SmartSockets message types, or a type previously defined with createMt(java.lang.String, int, java.lang.String).

Example: 

   // look up the message type named "foo"
   TipcMt mt = TipcSvc.lookupMt("foo");

Parameters:
name - name of the message type to return.
Returns:
the message type looked up, or null if the name does not refer to an existing message type.
See Also:
TipcMt, createMt(java.lang.String, int, java.lang.String), lookupMt(int)

lookupMt

public static TipcMt lookupMt(int number)
Returns a message type indexed by number. This message type must be one of the standard SmartSockets message types, or a type previously defined with createMt(java.lang.String, int, java.lang.String). The standard SmartSockets message types have numeric constants defined in TipcMt.

Example: 

   // look up the message type number 500
   TipcMt mt = TipcSvc.lookupMt(500);

Parameters:
number - the number of the message type to return.
Returns:
the message type looked up, or null if the number does not refer to an existing message type.
See Also:
TipcMt, createMt(java.lang.String, int, java.lang.String), lookupMt(int)

createMsg

public static TipcMsg createMsg(TipcMt mt)
Creates a new SmartSockets message of the specified message type.

Example: 

   // look up the message type number 500
   TipcMt mt = TipcSvc.lookupMt(500);
   // create a message of this type
   TipcMsg msg = TipcSvc.createMsg(mt);

Parameters:
mt - the message's message type.
Returns:
the new message, or null if the message type doesn't exist.
See Also:
TipcMt, TipcMsg

Example: 

   // create a message of the standard message type INFO
   TipcMsg msg = TipcSvc.createMsg(TipcMt.INFO);

Parameters:
mtNum - the message's message type number.
Returns:
the new message, or null if the message type doesn't exist.
See Also:
TipcMt, TipcMsg

createMsg

                                int offset,
                                int endian,
                                int realFormat,
                                int charFormat)
                         throws TipcException
Creates a new message by deserializing the contents of a byte array.

Parameters:
buf - a byte array containing the message to be deserialized
offset - index into buf indicating the start of the message
endian - INT_BIG_ENDIAN or INT_LITTLE_ENDIAN from TipcDefs.
realFormat - REAL_IEEE, REAL_DEC_D, REAL_DEC_G, REAL_370 from TipcDefs
charFormat - must be CHAR_US_ASCII from TipcDefs
Throws:
TipcMsgException - if there is an error deserializing the message
TipcException - for all other errors
See Also:
TipcMsg, TipcDefs

createConnClient

public static TipcConnClient createConnClient(java.lang.String lcn)
                                       throws TipcException
Creates a new peer-to-peer client connection. This method creates the client end of a peer-to-peer connection. The server end must be up and running prior to this call, so the client has something to connect to. The protocol, hostname, and port number for the connection are specified as a "logical connection name" (LCN), using the form: protocol:hostname:port. "_node" may be substituted for the local hostname.

Example: 

  // connect to a peer listening via TCP on host foo at port 8002
  TipcConnClient conn = TipcSvc.createConnClient("tcp:foo:8002");
  // create a SmartSockets message and send it to the server
  TipcMsg msg = TipcSvc.createMsg(TipcMt.INFO);
  msg.appendStr("hello");
  conn.send(msg);
  conn.flush();

Parameters:
lcn - the logical connection name to use for the connection
Returns:
the connection object
Throws:
TipcBadArgumentException - if the LCN is invalid
TipcTimeoutException - for connection timeouts
TipcAssertionException - if the LCN hostname is unknown
TipcMsgException - for corrupt initialization messages
TipcIOException - for lower-level errors
TipcNotFoundException - when the protocol driver cannot be found
TipcProxyException - for errors when connecting to a proxy server
TipcException - for all other errors
See Also:
TipcConnClient

createConnServer

public static TipcConnServer createConnServer(java.lang.String lcn)
                                       throws TipcException
Create a new peer-to-peer server connection. This method creates the server end of a peer-to-peer connection. The protocol, hostname, and port number are specified using the same "logical connection name" (LCN) as the client connection.

This connection is only used to accept connections from clients. All actual communication is done with the client connection returned by TipcConnServer.accept().

Example: 

  // create the server-side of a connection listening via TCP on port 8002
  TipcConnServer srvConn = TipcSvc.createConnServer("tcp:_node:8002");
  // accept a client connection
  TipcConnClient conn = srvConn.accept();
  // get the next message sent by the client
  TipcMsg msg = conn.next(10.0);

Parameters:
lcn - the logical connection name to use for the connection
Returns:
the new connection interface
Throws:
TipcBadArgumentException - if the LCN is invalid
TipcAssertionException - if the LCN hostname is unknown
TipcIOException - for lower-level errors
TipcException - for all other errors
See Also:
TipcConnServer, TipcConnClient

createSrv

public static TipcSrv createSrv()
Creates a new TipcSrv RTserver connection object.

Warning: Normally one should always use getSrv() to get the single, global connection to the RTserver. This method should only be used when multiple connections are absolutely necessary. This situation occurs in environments where multiple instances of SmartSockets clients reside within the same Java Virtual Machine, such as multiple Servelets in a web server or multiple Applets in a browser. Maintaining multiple connections to an RTserver will degrade performance slightly.

All RTserver connections share a common set of options set by the option assessor methods in the Tut class. Option values for a particular connection object may be overridden by using the option assessor methods available to the TipcSrv object, inherited from the TipcConnClient interface.

The one exception is the ss.unique_subject option. A new default unique subject will be generated for each TipcSrv object created by the this method.

Note: this method will not create a connection to RTserver. Use the TipcSrv.create(int, byte[]) method to do this. The methods to send and receive messages will also automatically connect to RTserver.

Example: 

   // create a new connection object
   TipcSrv srv = TipcSvc.createSrv();
   // set the unique subject of the connection
   srv.setOption("ss.unique_subject", "/publish_client");
   // create the connection to the RTserver
   srv.create();

RTserver must be running before a connection is made. The Java library does not attempt to start an instance of RTserver.

Returns:
a new TipcSrv object
Since:
SmartSockets 6.0
See Also:
TipcSrv, getSrv()

getSrv

public static TipcSrv getSrv()

Gets the global TipcSrv RTserver connection object.

Note: this method will not create a connection to RTserver. Use the TipcSrv.create(int, byte[]) method to do this. The methods to send and receive messages will also automatically connect to RTserver.

Example: 

   // get the instance of the connection to the RTserver
   TipcSrv srv = TipcSvc.getSrv();
   // create a SmartSockets message to publish
   TipcMsg msg = TipcSvc.createMsg(TipcMt.ALERT);
   msg.setDest("/foo");
   msg.appendStr("warning!");
   // TipcSrv.send will automatically connect to the RTserver if not already
   srv.send(msg);
   srv.flush();

RTserver must be running before a connection is made. The Java library does not attempt to start an instance of RTserver.

Returns:
the current TipcSrv object
See Also:
TipcSrv

validSubject

public static boolean validSubject(java.lang.String subject)
Checks that the subject is valid. Invalid subjects are null or empty subjects, those with only whitespace between subject delimiters.

Parameters:
subject - the subject to check
Returns:
true if the subject is valid, false otherwise.

matchSubjects

public static boolean matchSubjects(java.lang.String subj1,
                                    java.lang.String subj2)
Matches two subject strings, one or both of which may be wildcarded.

Note: Subjects are not case sensitive.

Parameters:
subj1 - the first subject
subj2 - the second subject
Returns:
true if they match, false otherwise

makeSubjectAbsolute

public static java.lang.String makeSubjectAbsolute(java.lang.String os)
If the subject is not absolute (doesn't start with "/"), tack on the default subject prefix, if it exists. If the prefix isn't set to anything, it simply returns the original name untouched. This method should only be invoked when using the global RTserver connection via the getSrv() method. Otherwise, use TipcSrv.makeSubjectAbsolute.

Parameters:
os - the subject to make absolute.
Returns:
the absolute subject.
